STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 11, 2025
AMENDED
Romell G Green
Wayne County DHHS-South Central
1801 E Canfield St,
Detroit, MI, 48207-4635
RE: License#: CP820201496
Dear Mr. Green:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/27/2024. A Preliminary exit conference was held with your agency on 12/30/2024.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing on the CWL-4617 Acknowledgement
of appeal rights. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must notify this
office in writing. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must still
submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
(248) 860-3317
Enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
AMENDED (for Analyst note 3-17-25)
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201496
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Romell G Green
Name of Agency: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - SOUTHCENTRAL
Agency Address: 1801 E CANFIELD ST
DETROIT, MI 48207-4635
Agency Telephone #: 313-578-5102
Original Issuance Date: 09/03/1993
Service Types: Place children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

B. Analyst

Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services
worker for purposes of providing direct services in
foster care, independent living, adoption, or post
adoption services or a combination thereof.
10 of 51 foster care workers had caseloads over 15. Five of the 10 had caseloads
ranging from 18 to 20 cases.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
10 of 27 personnel records reviewed did not show compliance related to either a
three-month probationary evaluation for a new employee, six-month evaluation

for an employee who transferred positions, or an annual evaluation for an
employee employed over one year:
• Five employee's probationary evaluation due by 6/15/2024, 7/27/024,
9/24/2024 ,12/1/2024 and 12/15/2024 were completed late on their
respective 7/10/2024, 10/22/2024, 10/29/2024, 12/16/2024; and
12/18/2024 completion date.
• A sixth employee's probationary evaluation due by 12/15/2024 was not
documented. It is noted that employee reportedly resigned on 12/17/2024.
• A seventh and eighth employee had a six-month evaluation due by
4/12/2024 and 10/15/2024. Both performance evaluations were completed
late on their respective 7/22/2024 and 12/16/2024 completion date.
• A ninth and tenth employee’s annual performance evaluation due by
8/28/2024 and 8/31/2024 were completed late on 12/17/2024 and
12/30/2024 respectively.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
(iii) Height and weight.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child’s height and weight at placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child's eye and hair color at placement.

Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
(v) Identifying marks.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation as to
whether the child had any identifying marks at placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(a) All the following child characteristics:
(vi) Religious or spiritual preference.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child’s religious preference at placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(6) An agency must document, in the child's record,
within 7 calendar days after placement, the information
specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the following
information:
(g) Documentation of the child's placement preparation.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child's preparation for placement.

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the
reason why return is not possible.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
why the child was not returned to the parent, related to the child's replacement on
4/24/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed
with a relative, then the reason why those placements
are not possible.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
why the child was not reunited with siblings, related to the child's replacement on
4/24/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
required placement considerations, related to the child's replacement on
4/24/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
replacement preparation related to the child's replacement on 4/24/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
reuqired notifications, related to the child's replacement on 4/24/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation the
new placmenet was provided information about the child, related to the child's
replacement on 4/24/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
One of three closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
a summary of the services provided up to the time of replacmeent and needs that
remain to be met. A DHS-69 utilized to record this information was not completed.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.

One of three closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(b). A DHS-69 utilized to record this information was not documented.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child's dental was due by 9/10/2024 and
completed late on 9/25/2024.
• A second record showed the child's dental was due by 3/6/2024 and
completed late on 4/4/2024.
• A third record showed the child's dental due by 12/2/2024 was not
documented.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s 9-month
dental due by 12/23/2023 was not documented.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that information related to the
child's health was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial placement
on 6/11/2024, or to the child's caregiver at the child's replacement on
6/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation that information related to
the child's health was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial
placement on 12/7/2023 or to the child's respective caregivers at the
child's replacement on 1/10/2024, 3/1/2024 and 11/26/2024.
• A third record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement outline
utlized to show documentation of (c) completed by the worker was not
signed by the caregiver. I could not discern if the required information was
provided to the caregiver related to the child's replacement on 8/2/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that information related to the
child's health, as required by(c) was provided to the caregiver at the child’s
initial placement on 4/12/2024. A DHS-3307 was completed but it was not
signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver
• A fifth and sixth record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement
outline utlized to show documentation of (c) completed by the worker for
the respective child’s initial placement on 6/13/2024 and 7/17/2024 but the
information related to (c) was indicated as N/A. Therefore, it could not be
determined if the required information was provided to the respective
caregiver.
• A seventh record did not show documentation that information related to
the child's health was provided to the caregiver for the child’s 8/27/2024
placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim February 2024; CAP Approved
4/19/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that information related to any
known history of abuse/neglect for the child was provided to the caregiver
at the child’s initial placement on 6/11/2024, or to the child's caregiver at
the child's replacement on 6/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation that information related to
any known history of abuse/neglect for the child was provided to the
caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 12/7/2023 or to the child's
respective caregivers at the child's replacement on 1/10/2024, 3/1/2024
and 11/26/2024.
• A third record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement outline
utlized to show documentation of (d) completed by the worker, but it was
not signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver related to the child's
replacement on 8/2/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that information related to any
known history of abuse/neglect for the child, as required by (d) was
provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 4/12/2024. A
DHS-3307 was completed but not signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it
could not be determined if the required information was provided to the
caregiver.
• A fifth and sixth record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement
outline utlized to show documentation of(d) completed by the worker for
the respective child’s initial placement on 6/13/2024 and 7/17/2024, but the
information related to (d) was indicated as N/A. Therefore, it could not be
determined if the required information was provided to the respective
caregiver.
• A seventh record did not show documentation that information related to
any known history of abuse/neglect for the child was provided to the
caregiver for the child’s 8/27/2024 placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that information related to the
child’s emotional and psychological factors was provided to the caregiver
at the child’s initial placement on 6/11/2024, or to the child's caregiver at
the child's replacement on 6/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation that information related to
the child’s emotional and psychological factors was provided to the
caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 12/7/2023 or to the child's
respective caregivers at the child's replacement on 1/10/2024, 3/1/2024
and 11/26/2024.
• A third record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement outline
utlized to show documentation of (e) completed by the worker, but it was
not signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver related to the child's
replacement on 8/2/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that information related to the
child’s emotional and psychological factors was provided to the caregiver
at the child’s initial placement on 4/12/2024. A DHS-3307 was completed
but not signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver.
• A fifth and sixth record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement
outline utlized to show documentation of(e) was completed by the worker
for the respective child’s initial placement on 6/13/2024 and 7/17/2024, but
the information related to (e) was indicated as N/A. Therefore, it could not
be determined if the required information was provided to the respective
caregiver.
• A seventh record did not show documentation that information related to
the child’s emotional and psychological factors was provided to the
caregiver for the child’s 8/27/2024 placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that information related to the
child’s known behaviors was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial
placement on 6/11/2024, or to the child's caregiver at the child's
replacement on 6/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation that information related to
the child’s known behaviors was provided to the caregiver at the child’s
initial placement on 12/7/2023 or to the child's respective caregivers at the
child's replacement on 1/10/2024, 3/1/2024 and 11/26/2024.
• A third record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement outline
utlized to show documentation of (f) completed by the worker, but was not
signed by the caregive. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver related to the child's
replacement on 8/2/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that information related to the
child’s known behaviors was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial
placement on 4/12/2024. A DHS-3307 was completed but not signed by
the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the required
information was provided to the caregiver
• A fifth and sixth record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement
outline utlized to show documentation of (e) completed by the worker for
the respective child’s initial placement on 6/13/2024 and 7/17/2024, but the
information related to (f) was indicated as N/A. Therefore, it could not be
determined if the required information was provided to the respective
caregiver.
• A seventh record did not show documentation that information related to
the child’s known behaviors, as required by (f) was provided to the
caregiver for the child’s 8/27/2024 placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that information related to (g) was
provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 6/11/2024, or to
the child's caregiver at the child's replacement on 6/13/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation that information related to (g)
was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 12/7/2023
or to the child's respective caregivers at the child's replacement on
1/10/2024, 3/1/2024, and 11/26/2024.
• A third record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement outline
utlized to show documentation of (g) completed by the worker, but was not
signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it could not be determined if the
required information was provided to the caregiver related to the child's
replacement on 8/2/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation that information related to (g)
was provided to the caregiver at the child’s initial placement on 4/12/2024.
A DHS-3307 was completed but not signed by the caregiver. Therefore, it
could not be determined if the required information was provided to the
caregiver.
• A fifth and sixth record showed documentation of a DHS-3307 Placement
outline utlized to show documentation of (g) completed by the worker for
the respective child’s initial placement on 6/13/2024 and 7/17/2024, but the
information related to (g) was indicated as N/A. Therefore, it could not be
determined if the required information was provided to the respective
caregiver.
• A seventh record did not show documentation that information related to
(g) was provided to the caregiver for the child’s 8/27/2024 placement.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Eight of eight open foster child records reviewed had treatment plans that were
not signed timely which indicates the plans were not reviewed with the caregivers
and/or parents timely. Also, many treament plans were not uploaded into
MISACWIS.
• One record showed the child’s 6/11/2024-7/9/2024 initial treatment plan
was not signed by the caregiver until 12/29/2024.
• A second record showed the child’s 12/7/23-1/5/2024 treatment plan was
not signed by the birth mother until 3/24/2024. The 1/6/2024-4/2/2024
treatment plan was not signed by the birth mother until 5/30/2024, the
4/3/2024-6/27/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the child’s caregiver,
and the birth mother did not sign this plan until 9/5/2024. The next USP
6/28/2024-9/25/2024 was not signed by the child’s birth parent or
caregiver.
• A third record showed the child’s 1/19/2024-4/26/2024 treatment plan was
not signed by the birth parent. The mother’s name was typed on the
signature line, but not dated. It could not be determined if the plan was
signed timely. The 4/26/2024-7/14/2024 treatment plan was not signed by
the birth parents and caregiver. A copy of the plan was later provided, it
was signed on 12/27/2024. The 7/15/2024-10/11/2024 treatment plan was
not documented at the time of the review. The 7/15/2024- 10/11/2024
treatment plan signed by the worker and supervisor was provided later and
was dated 12/27/2024.
• A fourth record did not show documentation of a 4/12/2024-5/10/2024
initial treatment plan, a 5/11/2024-8/8/2024, or 8/9/2024-11/4/2024
updated treatment plan signed by the worker, supervisor, caregiver, or
birth parent.
• A fifth record did not show documentation of the worker’s, supervisor’s,
caregiver’s, and birth parents’s signature on the child’s 8/19/2024 initial
treatment plan.

• A sixth record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s signature on
the child’s 7/17/2024-8/15/2024 initial treatment plan. The agency provided
documentation of this treatment plan after the review. It was signed by the
caregiver on 12/27/2024.
• A seventh record did not show documentation of the supervisor’s,
caregiver’s, or birth parent’s signature on the child’s 6/13/2024-7/12/2024
initial treatment plan. The agency provided documentation of this treatment
plan after the review. It was signed by each of those parties on 1/2/2025.
This child’s next treatment plan 7/13/2024-10/10/2024 was also not signed
by the parties, or the worker. The agency provided documentation showing
that each of these parties signed this updated treatment plan on 1/2/2025.
• A eighth record did not show documentation of the youth’s or caregiver’s
signature on the child’s 8/19/2024 initial treatment plan.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection- February 2024, cited
under FOM 722-8D; CAP Approved 4/19/2024. Renewal Inspection-2023,
cited under ISEP 6.19(5)(c) & FOM 722-8D; CAP Approved 1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans must be signed by the social services
worker and the social services supervisor.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed had various service plans
which were not signed by the worker and or supervisor.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
In four of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's ISP did not show
documentation of the child's placement selection criteria. The information was left
blank in one and not recorded in the others.
Repeat Violation Established: Interim Inspection February 2024; CAP
Approved 4/19/2024. Renewal Inspection- 2023; CAP Approved 1/27/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's ISP did not show
documentation of a child specific behavior support plan to be used by the foster
parent.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's updated service plan
(USP) did not show documentation of a child specific behavior support plan to be
used by the foster parent.
Repeat Violation Established: Renewal Inspection 2023; CAP Approved
1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record.
(3) The record must contain all the following
information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually.
Two of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a child's photo after
12/21/2020. The child's case closed 6/19/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation of a 2023 photo for the child,
whose case closed 11/17/2024.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The agency was/is advised to timely upload required documents to
MISACWIS.
• R400.12404(6)(h) Placement: The agency was advised ensuring that a copy
of the child’s photo is timely uploaded to the required section of MISACWIS
may aid it in showing compliance with this rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s Interim
inspection where the agency received 22 rule violations.
During this current inspection the agency’s renewal license, the agency received
28 rule violations. This was an increase from the last inspection. Of these 27
citations, 18 are repeat violations within the last two years (12 are specific repeats
violation from the last inspection). The agency’s CAP compliance around these 12
rule violations is as follows: the number of individual cases increased in all 12
cited areas this indicates that the corrective actions put in place to correct the
deficiencies are not effective.
Electronic and or physical documents/tools were reviewed for verification of CAP
compliance and the above reporting showed that the agency, though it was able to
show that various action steps on its CAP were completed and or implemented,
the agency was not totally successful with all aspects of the CAP.
On a positive note, the agency did not have late service plans or missed home
visits with caregivers and children.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a chief administrator’s (CA) report dated 1/3/2025. The
report indicated information as denoted in its last inspection report with respect to
citations and the corrective action plan that was put forth. The CA indicated CPS

supervisors and foster care supervisors ensured that workers were documenting
required information for the child when completing placement paper work and
taking treatment plans with them monthly on home visits to obtain signatures.
Additionally, supervisors were reviewing the Book of Business for service plan due
dates, and section managers were utilizing outlook calendars to remind
supervisors and workers of task due dates. Furthermore, that training reported in
the CAP took place and that Key Performance Indicators (KPI) meeting happens
weekly.
During the entrance conference with the CA and Section Manager, who is new in
this position at South Central, both reported the KPI meetings have been helpful
with regards to monitoring aspects of the corrective action plan. Also, that having
the Health Liaison Officer (HLO) work with staff and be present at meetings has
been beneficial. The HLO involvement reportedly has aided the agency with
medical and dental completions. The agency also indicated that staff changes,
due to medical leaves, resignations, and position changes has impacted workers’
caseload sizes and rule compliance in some area. The CA and Section Manager
reported they are currently making plans to develop better systems so as to bring
about greater rule compliance.
Financial Overview
This is not applicable. This is a Department of Health and Human Services district
office.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the CA and Section Manager during the Entrance
and Exit conference, three foster care workers and one supervisor were
interviewed. The staff expressed appreciation for the administration’s openness to
change and transfers, and support from team members. Areas of concern, or
areas of improvement are related to the newness of the current administration with
respect to section managers and everyone learning their new roles, low staff
morale, high caseloads. improved communication across programs, more
acknowledgement/appreciation to workers, less threats, and more trust being
demonstrated. Additionally, a desire for higher wages given the higher amount of
case work.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not reveal any safety issues or concerns. Files
were secured and there was adequate space and equipment for staff.

VII. DCWL ANALYST FINDINGS
The Division of Child Welfare Licensing Analyst reported two safety alerts for the
agency this inspection.
Alert #1 from a foster home visit on 10/17/2024:
Concern:
The foster parent was co-sleeping with her toddler foster son. A toddler bed was
observed in the bedroom filled with clothing and other items. The foster parent
stated the child does not use the bed.
Resolution:
An agency supervisor made a home visit to the foster home on 10/18/2024. A safety
plan was discussed with the foster parent. The safety plan indicated the child’s bed
will be free of items, and the child will sleep in it. If the child experiences separation
anxiety the foster parent will encourage the child to sleep in the bed. Also, that the
foster parent will discuss the child’s anxiety issues with the therapist. The agency
reported the foster parent signed the safety plan and it was uploaded into
MISACWIS. The agency attached a copy of the safety plan.
Alert # 2 from an unlicensed relative home visit on 10/28/2024:
Concern:
An unlicensed relative’s home did not have an operable smoke detector on each
level of occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. Nor did the home have an
operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
An agency kinship specialist visited the home on 10/29/2024 and provided the
caregiver with three smoke/carbon monoxide detectors for the home. This worker
confirmed that the detectors were installed properly on each level of the home.
Alert # 3 from an unlicensed relative home visit on 10/24/25.
Concern:
An unlicensed relative’s home did not have an operable smoke detector on each
level of occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. Nor did the home have an
operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
An agency kinship specialist visited the home on 10/24/2024 and provided the
caregiver with three smoke/carbon monoxide detectors for the home. This worker
confirmed that the detectors were installed properly on each level of the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan modification of the agency’s
license to a first provisional license is recommended.
